text:
From the words lettered A to D, choose the word that best completes each of the following sentences.
Do you speak French? Only..........,I'm afraid'.

From the words lettered A to D, choose the word that best completes each of the following sentences.
Whatever you buy, always look for the .............bargain.

From the words lettered A to D, choose the word that best completes each of the following sentences.
We heard grandfather............the organ.
explanation:
When using the verb "heard" in the past tense, the action is already established in the past. The verb that follows should be in its base form (infinitive), not the past tense, because "heard" has already indicated the past.
The correct structure is to use the base form of the verb after "heard":
"We heard grandfather play the organ."

explanation:

text:
From the words lettered A to D, choose the word that best completes each of the following sentences.
This is an improvement...........your last report
explanation:
"This is an improvement on your last report."
"On" is the correct preposition used when talking about improvements in comparison to a previous thing or situation, such as a previous report. We use ‘improvement of,’ to refer to something becoming better. However, we mainly use this when talking about improvement in prospects. For example, ‘We anticipate the improvement of local public schools in the country.’ The prepositions "over" and "against" are not typically paired with the noun "improvement".

From the words lettered A to D, choose the word that best completes each of the following sentences.
The manager wanted to study the document..............the background of the latest development
explanation:
"The manager wanted to study the document against the background of the latest development."
The expression "against the background of (something)” is a figurative and imaginative way to describe what’s going on in the background or surrounding context when something else happens especially when you want to show the contrast or highlight the differences between both things or events.

From the words lettered A to D, choose the word that best completes each of the following sentences.
.............an ambulance, the child's life would have been saved
explanation: This sentence structure is an example of an inverted conditional sentence, often used to express a hypothetical situation in the past. The correct form is "had + subject + past participle," which is used to indicate a condition that was not fulfilled in the past but could have led to a different outcome. In this case, it suggests that if there had been an ambulance, the child's life could have been saved.

text:
From the words lettered A to D, choose the word that best completes each of the following sentences.
Really, I wouldn't say this to...........
explanation: The correct word to complete the sentence is"any other" (Option C). The phrase "Really, I wouldn't say this to any other" conveys that the speaker would not share this information or make the statement to anyone else apart from the person being addressed.

Only one of the contestants..........able to answer the question correctly
explanation:
"Only one of the contestants was able to answer the question correctly."
"Only one"refers to a singular subject, so it requires a singular verb. Therefore,"was"is the correct verb to use here.

The general wondered whether the new recruits were equal to the task ahead. This means that the general wasn't sure whether the new recruits

After each of the following sentences, a list of possible interpretations of the sentence is given. Choose the interpretation that you consider most appropriate for each sentence.
Not a single member of the board put in a good word for him. This means that

options.B: none of the members said anything favourable about him
options.C: some of the members disliked him
options.D: none of the members spoke kindly to him

explanation:
The sentence "Not a single member of the board put in a good word for him" suggests that no member of the board spoke favourably or positively about him. Let's break down the options:
A. all the members criticized him - This is not necessarily implied by the sentence. The absence of putting in a good word doesn't necessarily mean all members criticized him.
B. none of the members said anything favourable about him - This option is correct. It indicates that there was no positive endorsement or support from any board member.
C. some of the members disliked him - The sentence doesn't specify that some members disliked him; it simply states that no one spoke positively about him.
D. none of the members spoke kindly to him - While the sentence doesn't explicitly mention speaking kindly, the focus is on the absence of positive remarks or endorsements.
Option B, "none of the members said anything favourable about him," is the most appropriate interpretation because it shows that there was a lack of positive comments or support from any board member.

The marathon is a gruelling race

From the words lettered A to D below each of the following sentences, choose the word that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word.
The works of art in this gallery are priceless
explanation:
When you say something is invaluable it means it has so much value that it cant be quantified. And that is exactly what priceless means. something that is so valuable, precious, useful and important that you cant put a price on it.
Example; The air we breath is invaluable, priceless.
Invaluable means priceless, extremely useful; indispensable.

explanation: The underlined word"intake"refers to the admission or enrollment of new students into the university. The opposite of intake would be the rejection of students by the university, which is best captured by"rejections".

From the words lettered A to D, choose the word that best completes each of the following sentences:
Mr Cham will never tell you everything, he's very..........
explanation: If Mr. Cham will never tell you everything and is described as "very secretive," it implies that he tends to keep things private or concealed. "Secretive" means inclined to keep things secret or to keep one's thoughts, actions, or intentions hidden from others. Therefore, in the given sentence, the word "secretive" appropriately conveys the idea that Mr. Cham is not open or transparent in sharing information.
